item.title: Join Mina's zkIgnite, Cohort 1
item.description: zkIgnite, Cohort 1 will start in Q1 2023 and provide hands-on support and funding to those wanting to build on zero knowledge (ZK) – from ideation, technical mentorship, to funding your proof of concept and even VC support afterwards. There will be a variety of opportunities and grants for different participants and those who participated in Cohort 0 are encouraged to apply.

item.title: Mastinator: Public Apology
Preparing for Less Privacy
item.description: An old privacy post of mine recently got a lot of discussion on Hacker News. It seems people took me to be saying something like: Other people are foolish to be worried about privacy. If there's anything you don't want public it's probably because you're doing something you shouldn't. The decrease in privacy over time will be great for everyone once we adapt to it, and has no downsides. To b
item.author: (Jeff Kaufman)

item.title: Random thoughts from Lucas Kostka
item.description: ChatGPT capabilities are astonishing and frightening, to me at least. Still, when taking a deeper look at it, playing with it, I feel like that this will not be as groundbreaking as one may fear, in its current version and immmediate present at least. Listing a couple of limitations I have observed and commented on in some other places so that I do not forget.

item.title: The Best C# .NET Web Application Tech Stack: Choosing a Database
item.description: We continue on our path to make a web application using C# and .NET. After choosing the front-end technology in part 1, picking the backend server tech in part 2, and deploying to Azure in part 3, we’re going to concentrate on choosing the database. With emphasis on .NET and Azure technologies of course. A database, or rather databases, is one of the most important aspects of any big application. The database choice can either cause or prevent latency bottlenecks, data consistency issues, availability problems, and development complexity.
